ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan Penagos Zuluaga
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan was brilliant, especially in the field - always excited to point out species and explain concepts to students.
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  good
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan Penagos Zuluaga
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan Penagos Zuluaga

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  He was very nice and available for questions. He was very responsive and helpful, and was passionate about the subject and cared deeply for student learning. However, I don't think many people asked for his help before our trip. On the trip he was an amazing TA, and afterwards he took it upon himself to help us with our write ups. I don't know if there is a way to have him integrated into the course more at the beginning.
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  He was really knowledgeable about tropical plants and systems, and was always eager to help.
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Knowledgeable, always accessible, open and friendly.

Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan was extremely approachable. He had a great style of pushing us to think harder but never can across negative. It was a great balance. The one way he may improve was to expand his academic conversations to topics outside of botany/taxonomy. I recognize this is his expertise but I am sure he has much more to share.

Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan was a fantastic TA. He was so friendly and accessible, in New Haven and in Panama. There was no question, large or small, that I felt uncomfortable asking him. Beyond this, he knew the material like the back of his hand. A mentor and a friend, Juan is someone whom I hope to keep in touch with and to continue learning from.

Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Really excellent teaching fellow, very available and interested in the topic, and very knowledgable. We got to interact with him a lot in Panama, and he was crucial to the amazing experience we had. I really have no weaknesses to report in Juan, he is the best TF that I have had here at Yale.
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Enthusiastic and well informed. Gave a delightful lecture on plant identification.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The major strength of the course was the time spent in the field, and the writing up of the research afterwards. It was incredible to be immersed in the field and meet all these scientists and learn of their research. Conducting a study and following proper protocol for scientific submission was very helpful to learn the rigorous process behind scientific experiments and knowledge. The first half of the course did not seem all that relevant to the field trip. It has been explained that the course in the fall is meant to provide a detailed background to understand tropical ecology, yet without that course this year, many of us had trouble connecting what we were reading with the relevance to the class.

I thought the pace was too slow initially, and only really picked up for the field trip. I think it would have been useful to prepare a bit more before we got into the field, especially around plant ID and ecological theories. Although the latter made a lot more sense while we were actually in the field.
I think this course was really heavy on the botany. I would like to see more conversation around topics such as fauna and sociology.
This course was excellent. I really feel that I got a lot out of it.

The field trip was extremely helpful to my learning about tropical field ecology-- I learned an incredible amount by being there and seeing the research station. It was an incredible experience that really inspired excitement for learning more about tropical ecology. However, overall I did not find that the professors were excited about the material, or interested in advancing our learning. We did not get a good foundation in ecological theory or concepts before we went to Panama-- because we only met once a week, we didn't have a lot of time to learn about the concepts before our trip. Our discussions were not very helpful, and I didn't feel that the professors did very much to provoke conversation.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip to Panama, we learned so much. I sincerely appreciate how flexible and adaptive the professors and the TA were to tailor it to student interests, and how much they cared about our learning.

The best aspects were the chance to get into the field and see how these ecological forces and theories were interacting in practice. It was useful to get a sense of how data is collected and the limitations for studying these issues. However, I would have liked more focus on tropical ecology basics and theories in a more formalized setting. I feel like I have a sense of the interactions more now, but not as strongly as i have when I left other similar classes that weren't specifically tropically focused. Professors were also great at responding to class interest and flexible in class and on the field trip. The places we went were a pretty amazing selection of sites, and it was a pretty incredible 10 day trip!
The field trip was a great opportunity to see things on-the-ground, see research sites and get an "on-the-ground" attempt at practicing tropical ecology.
Excellent field trip.
the field trip was very well organized and ran extremely smoothly. I understand that this is no easy feat. Great job!
Learning the literature and being out in the field

The trip to panama was, of course, the highlight of the semester. In the ecosystem that we'd been reading about, we were learning so much each day. The teachers were open to endless questions and were very attentive and excited. It was awesome to see them in their element.

The field trip was extremely well organized and packed full of useful information. A very intensive and complete overview of tropical field ecology and management issues faced in the tropics. Good combination of biology exposure with management application (such as the Aqua Salud visit).

The trip was great. I especially enjoyed interacting with researchers on BCI. I think that getting the course to such an active field station was critical to it's success. Hanging out at the school house was nice but it also meant that there was less informal learning going on. The canopy crane was amazing.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: the beginning half, see question 16.

I think having the fall tropical ecology lecture class will help this course a lot, as it won't all have to be a part of this one course. Because I would have liked some more back ground on tropical ecology as it is understood now. All the other ecology courses at FES I've seen are naturally more temperate focused, so I was really looking forward to digging into tropical questions specifically. We got into a lot more of this knowledge when we got into the field, but I would have liked more before we left.

More preparation prior to the trip could have allowed for more time for creating and conducting our "studies" or more visits to sites and places. (Preparation being lectures on plant, and animal id, a preview into the process of designing a study, developing a hypothesis etc.) More lectures in addition to student discussion would have helped.
As mentioned previously, a more holistic perspective of tropical field ecology (incorporating more fauna and how humans affect ecology and how ecology affects humans).
More structured discussion in class. May help if professor explains more concepts and guides conversation more

This course was a bit awkard in that we didn't have a thorough introduction to the topics that we'd be studying. We were not lectured to about the ecosystem and its flora and fauana generally until we were in Panama. I understand that this is because it is meant to be accompanied by a fall course that didn't run this year. Taking both courses may completely eliminate this small complaint. But because some students may only be able to take the spring field course, I would recommend some introductory lectures on the ecosystem (flora, fauna, history of the landscape, biotic +abiotic processes) in the first few days of classes.

I think that the readings and student lead discussions could be improved a bit - perhaps with a bit more guidance early on in terms of what is expected for a student led discussion. I think that some of the students were not sure how to lead a thought provoking discussion or how seriously to take things, though really it's the student's responsibility to strive.

The pre-panama section of the class was very boring. It is hard to get a class of such diverse backgrounds onto the same page to have meaningful discussions. Lectures by the professor that framed the paper we were reading and pointed out why we should be interested would be improve this section. Also the discussion sometimes got well outside of the professors wheel house in terms of content. This leaded to some pretty low level uninformed discussion of things like ecosystem services. During the trip there were multiple times when we had the group gathered but the instructors where still working out the plan of action. This should/could be shorted out before hand and would improve the flow of the course. The period after spring break seemed two short to prepare to papers meaningfully. Doing two papers also felt like busy work. It would be better to have a presentation on the first project and a paper about the second.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I felt that there could be a bit more lecturing by the professors. Many of us were new to these topics so some professor lead discussions would have been a great supplement. This may work itself out if people are required to take a prerequisite. However, if this is the case, you will loose the class diversity, which I felt was a major strength.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I do not have a natural science background, so this was focused on rounding that out, especially with more knowledge of tropical systems.
This was the only ecology course I took.
This could was good in terms of giving me exposure to field work, which I don't have a lot of experience with. This is part of my reason for coming to graduate school.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to gain more of a scientific understanding to tropical ecology since I usually work in social ecology. I wanted a scientific foundation to make strong management decisions.
I do not have a natural science background, so this was focused on rounding that out, especially with more knowledge of tropical systems.
I'm interested in tropical forestry and resource management
I wanted to supplement my social science courses and the field trip was extremely appealing.

I took this course to get into the field and experience the easily romanticized field work of ecologists first hand. It was fantastic. The challenges were clear, but not deterring. I did not expect to get a far better grip on the process of writing a scientific paper from this class, but I did. The idea of posing and addressing an ecological question is now far less intimidating. Very happy with the tools and experiences that this class has given me.
To gain insight on systems that I wasn't originally highly familiar with. To expand my exposure to field ecology.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I still would like a broader foundation of the big picture of tropical field ecology, but I understand the scientific process and enjoyed learning to conduct our own experiments.

I would have liked to leave with a bit more of a holistic picture of tropical ecology, but that might also be a reflection of how little information there actually are on these interactions, so hard to know if that was the framework of the class, or just a function of the field. I definitely have an appreciation for that uncertainty now.
Yes, I have learned that nature is more complicated than I have thought.

Yes, I felt it was a bit overwhelming sometimes because I didn't have a strong botany or statistics background. However, I felt that I got a lot out of the course although some aspects I didn't fully retain.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We had two different groups. One group was extremely cohesive and helpful and worked together in writing up our research. The other group had very smart people, but were unresponsive and did not want to work together. It's about the personalities of the people in the group. I definitely could not have done everything required on my own, and it was good to see how collaboration in the scientific community could work.
Group work was really helpful as everyone was great and we learned a lot from each other.

Made working through the process of conducting and writing a paper more possible. Challenge came from the fact that the groupwork was overlapping and involved a lot of coordination, but I don't think this could be avoided.

The major advantage was drawing on the variety of expertise within my group. I would not have been able to preform the statistics in particular or have the background to create a detailed research question outside of my existing knowledge base. The disadvantage was that I felt, in one group in particular, I didn't have much of a say in the content of the final version of the paper. One person in particular re-edited the paper and eliminated much of my work which in most cases were edits suggested by the peer reviews. With that said, I feel that the peer review process was extremely helpful as a writer and a reviewer.
Peer review process

It was wonderful to work in groups on our research projects. With three people, more creative brianstorming could be done to get around all the complications that accompany only a day and a half of data collection.
I think group work is great for a course like this. Group projects in general went quite smoothly and were guided well by the instructors.
It gave us the opportunity to collect out own data and analyze it, write a paper and respond to critiques by peers.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the fall course first. Be flexible and have an open mind, and do not be afraid to discuss what you want to see and learn.

Take the fall course first, if that is offered. Otherwise, it is really fun and the field trip especially is a great way to see how things are actually being done in practice, and to see some incredible ecological principles in action!
Even if you don't have a strong botany background, take it anyway.
Take an actual course on field ecology beforehand
Be prepared before go to class
Go for it! It's a great field course!
Take it, I learned so much from the field experience and research projects we did.
